{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Arsen Dedić | image = DedicArsenCropped.png | image_size = | alt = | caption = Arsen Dedić in 2006 | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Arsenije Dedić{{sfn|Lopušina|2008}} | native_name = | native_name_lang = | alias = Arsen
Igor Krimov
Luka Juras | birth_date = 28 July 1938 | birth_place = [[Šibenik]], [[Littoral Banovina]], [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia]] | origin = | death_date = {{Death date and age|2015|8|17|1938|7|28|df=y}} | death_place = [[Zagreb]], [[Croatia]] | genre = [[Chanson]], [[Pop music|Pop]] | occupation = Singer, songwriter, poet | instrument = | years_active = 1958–2015 | label = [[Jugoton]], [[Croatia Records]] | associated_acts = [[Gabi Novak]] | website = {{URL|arsen.hr}} }} '''Arsenije "Arsen" Dedić''' ({{IPA-hr|ǎrsen děːditɕ|pron}}; 28 July 1938 – 17 August 2015) was a [[Croats|Croatian]] singer-songwriter. Dedić wrote and performed [[chanson]]s as well as film music. He was also an award-winning poet and was one of the best-selling poets of former Yugoslavia. ==Biography== Arsen Dedić was born in [[Šibenik]], in the [[Littoral Banovina]] of the [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia]] as the second child of Jovan Dedić and Veronika (née Mišković).{{sfn|Fuka|Kegelj|2015}}{{cite news | url = http://arhiva.kurir-info.rs/arhiva/2005/maj/24/ST-02-24052005.shtml | language = Serbian | first = Kurir | last = Info | newspaper = [[Kurir Info]] | title = MOJ BRAT ARSENIJE Intimna ispovest beogradskog slikara Milutina Dedića, rođenog brata poznatog zagrebačkog šansonjera srpskog porekla | date = 24 May 2005 | accessdate = 2015-08-21}}{{sfn|Lopušina|2008}}{{cite news | url = http://www.jutarnji.hr/nenad-polimac-otkriva-jedinu-tajnu-arsena-dedica-jednom-je-rekao---ja-se-ne-bojim-smrti-/1401380/ | language = Croatian | first = Nenad | last = Polimac | newspaper = [[Jutarnji list]] | title = NENAD POLIMAC PIŠE O JEDINOJ TAJNI ARSENA DEDIĆA Jednom je rekao: 'Ja se smrti ne bojim' | date = 19 August 2015 | accessdate = 2015-08-21}} His father Jovan was [[Serbs|ethnic Serb]],{{sfn|Lopušina|2008}} an Orthodox Christian,{{sfn|Fuka|Kegelj|2015}} while his mother Jelka was [[Croats|Croat]]{{sfn|Fuka|Kegelj|2015}} who converted from Catholicism to Orthodoxy after marrying Jovan. His father was a [[bricklayer]], volunteer [[firefighter]], and musician, and his mother was an [[illiterate]] housewife, whom Arsen later taught. Arsen was baptized in the Orthodox Church under the name Arsenije, after Archbishop [[Arsenije III Čarnojević]].{{sfn|Lopušina|2008}} He finished music school. He and his older brother Milutin Dedić left Šibenik for [[Zagreb]] and [[Belgrade]], respectively, in 1957.{{sfn|Lopušina|2008}} Arsen studied law at Zagreb but dropped out in 1959, enrolling in the [[Music Academy of Zagreb]], receiving a diploma in 1964. Arsen became a household name in the 1960s, thanks to pop music festivals and his brand of music, which was at first influenced by [[Dalmatia]]n folklore, but is mostly comparable to the French [[chanson]] genre. Throughout the decades Dedić became one of the most respected musicians in former [[SFR Yugoslavia]] and maintained this reputation to this day. Dedić died 17 August 2015 in Zagreb, Croatia. He was 77 years old. ==Personal life== Arsen Dedić was married to German-born Croatian pop singer [[Gabi Novak]]. Their son [[Matija Dedić]] is one of the most respected [[jazz]] musicians in Croatia, and has together with Marina a daughter "Lu".Svet.rs, [https://web.archive.org/web/20100602091232/http://www.svet.rs/clanak/arsen-dedi%C4%87-i-gabi-novak-na-putu-je-jo%C5%A1-jedno-unu%C4%8De Arsen Dedić i Gabi Novak: Na putu je još jedno unuče], Izvor: "Vecernji.hr" Objavljeno: 31 May 2010 – 20:12 They also had a daughter, Sandra. == Discography == === Albums released on vinyl === * ''Čovjek kao ja (1969)'' * ''Arsen 2 (1971)'' * ''Homo Volans {{Infobox person | name = Bhikhudan Gadhvi | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1948|09|19}} | birth_place = [[Kutiyana]], [[Porbandar district]], [[Gujarat]], India | death_date = | death_place = | restingplace = | restingplacecoordinates = | othername = | occupation = Folk singer
Song writer | yearsactive = | known for = [[Music of Gujarat|Gujarati folk music]] | spouse = Gajraba | children = One son |Brother = jiludan gadhvi | parents = | website = | signature = File:Bhikhudan Gadhvi Signature.svg | awards = [[Padma Shri]]
[[Sangeet Natak Akademi Award]]
Gujarat Gaurav Award
Shri Dula Bhaya Kag Award }} '''Bhikhudan Govindbhai Gadhvi''' (born 1948) is an Indian folk singer and songwriter, known as a proponent of ''[[Music of Gujarat|Dayro]]'', a narrative singing tradition of Gujarat.{{cite web | url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/three-from-gujarat-among-padma-awardees/ | title=Three from Gujarat among Padma awardees | publisher=Indian Express | date=25 January 2016 | accessdate=July 29, 2016}} He is a recipient of the Gujarat Gaurav Award of the Government of Gujarat and the [[Sangeet Natak Akademi Award]].{{cite web | url=http://www.sangeetnatak.gov.in/sna/Awardees.html#TraditionalFolkTribalDanceMusicTheatrePuppetry | title=SNA Awards | publisher=Sangeet Natak Akademi | date=2016 | accessdate=July 29, 2016}} The Government of India awarded him the fourth highest civilian honour of the [[Padma Shri]], in 2016, for his contributions to folk music.{{cite web | url=http://mha.nic.in/sites/upload_files/mha/files/PadmaAwards_25012016.pdf | title=Padma Awards | publisher=Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India | date=2016 | accessdate=January 3, 2016 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170803085913/http://mha.nic.in/sites/upload_files/mha/files/PadmaAwards_25012016.pdf | archive-date=2017-08-03 | dead-url=yes | df= }} == Biography == Bhikhudan Gadhvi was born on 19 September 1948 in [[manekvada]], a village in [[junagadh district]] of the Indian state of [[Gujarat]].{{cite web | url=http://www.divyabhaskar.co.in/news/SAU-JUN-OMC-gujarats-bhikhudan-gadhvi-to-get-padma-shri-award-5232393-PHO.html | title=Journey to the Padma Shri | publisher=Divya Bhaskar daily | work=News report | date=25 January 2016 | accessdate=July 29, 2016}}{{cite web | url=http://www.gujaraticlub.in/2010/03/f4ag_01.html | title=Folklore Rattan: Bhikhudana Gadhvi | publisher=Gujarati Club | work=Web article | date=2016 | accessdate=July 29, 2016 | author=Manoj Shukla}} He started singing at the age of ten and after completing his secondary school education, he made his debut as a singer at the age of 20.{{cite web | url=http://deshgujarat.com/2010/02/16/gujarats-bhikhudan-gadhvi-to-get-sangeet-natak-akademi-award/ | title=Gujarat’s Bhikhudan Gadhvi to get Sangeet Natak Akademi award | publisher=Desh Gujarat | date=16 February 2010 | accessdate=July 29, 2016}} Reading the works of [[Jhaverchand Meghani]] and [[Dula Bhaya Kag]] early in his life is reported to have inspired [[Gadhvi]] to take up song writing and he focused on Dayro tradition, a folk music tradition of Gujarat where the performer sings narrative stories. He has since performed in many countries such as the US, UK and Indonesia and has over 350 audio albums to credit which include popular tracks like ''Bhadanu Makan'' and ''Khandaninu Khamir''. Gadhvi received the ''Gujarat Gaurav Award'' of the Government of Gujarat before the [[Sangeet Natak Akademi]] awarded him the [[Sangeet Natak Akademi Award|Akademi Puraskar]] in 2009. The Government of India included him the [[Indian honours system|Republic Day honors]] list for the civilian honor of the [[Padma Shri]] in 2016. He is also a recipient of the Shri Dula Bhaya Kag Award. He is married to Gajraba and they have a son, Bharatbhai.{{cite web | url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/good-governance/gujarat/Anandiben-felicitates-folksinger-Bhikhudan-Gadhavi/articleshow/51681007.cms | title=Anandiben felicitates folksinger Bhikhudan Gadhavi | publisher=Times of India | date=4 April 2016 | accessdate=July 29, 2016}} The family lives in [[Junagadh]] in Gujarat. == Selected discography == * {{cite AV media | url=https://www.amazon.in/Bhikhudan-Gandhvi-Sankriti-Gadhvi/dp/B00IZZ09VW/ref=sr_1_3?s=music&ie=UTF8&qid=1469781622&sr=1-3 | title=Bhikhudan Gandhvi Sankriti | publisher=T Series | people=Bhikhudan Gadhvi, Hamir Gadhvi, Hemant Chauhan, Rohit P. Rathod, Prabhat Barot, Muldas Rathod | medium=MP3 CD | ASIN=B00IZZ09VW}} * {{cite AV media | url=https://www.amazon.in/Sheth-Sagalsha-Lokvarta-Bhikhudan-Gadhvi/dp/B001PEU54G/ref=sr_1_2?s=music&ie=UTF8&qid=1469781622&sr=1-2 | title=Sheth Sagalsha-Lokvarta | publisher=T Series | people=Bhikhudan Gadhvi | medium=Audio CD | year=2007 | ASIN=B001PEU54G}} * {{cite AV media | url=https://www.amazon.in/Lok-Katha-Bhakti-Bhikhudan-Gadhvi/dp/B00KQHIQSU/ref=sr_1_1?s=music&ie=UTF8&qid=1469781622&sr=1-1 | title=Katha Bhakti Ras | publisher=T Series | people=Bhikhudan Gadhvi, Kanji Bhuta Barot, Magan Vada, Rohit P. Rathod, Nanji Bhai Makwana, Popatgiri Bapu | medium=MP3 CD | year=2014 | ASIN=B00KQHIQSU}} == See also == {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Music of Gujarat]] *[[charan]] * [[Jhaverchand Meghani]] * [[Dula Bhaya Kag]] {{div col end}} {{portal|India|Music}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * {{cite web | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v56Ay2Qs18E | title=Dayro By Bhikhudan Gadhvi | publisher=Gujarati Jalso | work=[[YouTube]] video | date=2 September 2014 | accessdate=July 29, 2016}} == Further reading == * {{cite web | url=http://www.gujaraticlub.info/2010/03/f4ag_01.html | title=Folklore Rattan: Bhikhudana Gadhvi | publisher=Gujarati Club | work=Web article | date=2016 | accessdate=July 29, 2016 | author=Manoj Shukla}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gadhvi, Bhikhudan}} [[Category:Recipients of the Padma Shri in arts]] [[Category:Recipients of the Sangeet Natak Akademi Award]] [[Category:1948 births]] [[Category:People from Porbandar district]] [[Category:Indian male singer-songwriters]] [[Category:Indian male folk singers]] [[Category:Gujarati people]] [[Category:Gujarati-language singers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Singers from Gujarat]]

{{use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox person |name = Cesare Romiti |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=y|1923|6|24}} |birth_place = [[Rome]] |death_date = |death_place = |residence = |nationality = [[Italians|Italian]] |alma_mater = |occupation = Economist |years_active = |net_worth = |boards = |religion = |spouse = |children = Two sons |parents = |signature = |website = }}
'''Cesare Romiti''' (born 24 June 1923) is an [[Italians|Italian]] economist, businessman and former executive of both state-owned firms and private companies, including [[Fiat]] and [[Alitalia]]. His nickname was ''Il Duro'' or ''the tough guy'' when he was serving as the head of Fiat.<ref>{{cite news|title=Italy Convicts Fiat Chairman; Bars Him from Corporate Posts|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/10/business/italy-convicts-fiat-chairman-bars-him-from-corporate-posts.html|accessdate=25 April 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=10 April 1997}}</ref><ref name=VattimoGirard2010>{{cite book|author1=Gianni Vattimo|author2=René Noël Girard|title=Christianity, Truth, and Weakening Faith: A Dialogue|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6RwpU0QmC_0C&pg=PT109|accessdate=20 July 2013|year=2010|publisher=Columbia University Press|isbn=978-0-231-52041-6|page=109}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Romiti was born in [[Rome]] on 24 June 1923.<ref name=cton>{{cite web|title=Cesare Romiti|url=http://chinatibet.people.com.cn/6790937.html|publisher=China Tibet Online|accessdate=24 February 2015}}</ref> He received an economics and commercial sciences degree in 1945.<ref name=cton/>
==Career and activities== Romiti began his career at [[Bombrini-Parodi-Delfino|the Bombrini Parodi Delfino (BFD)]] munitions group in 1947.<ref name=cton/> When the group merged with Snia Viscosa in 1968, he began to serve as the latter's general financial director.<ref name=wolf17dec/> Next he joined [[Alitalia]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Alitalia—Airline To Divas & Popes—Flies To Sunset|url=http://www.financialexpress.com/story-print/105456|accessdate=20 January 2014|work=The Financial Express|date=5 May 2004|agency=Reuters|location=Rome}}</ref> In December 1970, he became a board member of Alitalia and then was appointed general manager and chief executive of the company.<ref name=cton/> His term at the company lasted until 1973.<ref name=VattimoGirard2010/> In September 1973, he became the chief executive officer of the IRI finance firm, Italstat.<ref name=wolf17dec/>
Romiti worked for [[Fiat]] in various capacities for twenty years from 1974 to 1995.<ref name=wolf17dec>{{cite news|author=Wolfang Achtner|title=The tough cop takes the wheel; profile; Cesare Romiti|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/the-tough-cop-takes-the-wheel-profile-cesare-romiti-1526100.html|accessdate=25 April 2013|newspaper=The Independent|date=17 December 1995}}</ref> He was also one of the major shareholders of the company.<ref name=alan1212/> He succeeded [[Gianni Agnelli]] as the chairman of the firm when Agnelli stepped down.<ref name=alan1212>{{cite news|author=Alan Friedman|title=Successor at Automaker is 72 and a Target of Prosecutors|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/12/news/12iht-fiat.t.html|accessdate=25 April 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=12 December 1995}}</ref> Romiti led the firm from 28 February 1996 to 22 June 1998.<ref name=cton/> Romiti was instrumental in the company's return to profitability during this period.<ref>{{cite news|author=Jon Glover|title=Giovanni Agnelli|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2003/jan/24/guardianobituaries.italy|accessdate=20 July 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=24 January 2003}}</ref> Paolo Fresco succeeded him in the aforementioned post.<ref>{{cite news|author=Alan Friedman|title=Embattled Fiat Chief to Resign in June and Be Succeeded by the No. 2 at GE|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/23/business/worldbusiness/23iht-fiat.t_0.html|accessdate=25 April 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=23 January 1998|location=Rome}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=BMW confident as sales charge to pounds 2Obn record|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/BMW+confident+as+sales+charge+to+pounds+2Obn+record.-a060860908|accessdate=12 June 2013|newspaper=The Birmingham Post|date=30 January 1998}}</ref>
Romiti was the chairman of the board of RCS Quotidiani S.p.A. from 2 June 1998 to 15 July 2004.<ref name=cton/> Next he served as the chairman of [[Impregilo]] from May 2005 to 2007.<ref name=mfashions>{{cite web|title=Romiti|url=http://www.fashionsummit.it/en/2012-italy-china-edition/speakers/romiti|work=Milano Fashion Summit|accessdate=25 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Impregilo appoints Cesare Romiti chairman, Alberto Lina CEO|url=http://www.finanznachrichten.de/nachrichten-2005-05/1902193-impregilo-appoints-cesare-romiti-chairman-alberto-lina-ceo-020.htm|accessdate=25 April 2013|work=AFX News|date=2 May 2005|location=Milan}}</ref> He became the president of Italian China Institution in 2000 and was also appointed its president in 2004.<ref name=mfashions/><ref name="donuni">{{cite web|title=Cesare Romiti, President of Italian China Foundation, Appointed Consulting Professor of DHU|url=http://www2.dhu.edu.cn/dhuxxxt/shownewsenglish.asp?id=9930|publisher=Donghua University|accessdate=25 April 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150224211510/http://www2.dhu.edu.cn/dhuxxxt/shownewsenglish.asp?id=9930|archivedate=24 February 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> He is also advisor professor at [[Donghua University]].<ref name=donuni/>
===Controversy=== In April 1997, Romiti was convicted of falsifying the company accounts, committing tax fraud and making illegal payments to political parties.<ref name=alan1997>{{cite news|author=Alan Friedman|title=Fiat's 'Tough Guy' Chairman Is Found Guilty of Corruption|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/10/news/10iht-fiat.t.html|accessdate=20 July 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=10 April 1997}}</ref>
==Personal life== Romiti is married and has two sons.<ref name=wolf17dec/>
===Honours, awards and recognition=== Romiti has been awarded by various organizations, including the Chinese people’s association for friendship with foreign countries.<ref name="donuni">{{cite web|title=Cesare Romiti, President of Italian China Foundation, Appointed Consulting Professor of DHU|url=http://www2.dhu.edu.cn/dhuxxxt/shownewsenglish.asp?id=9930|publisher=Donghua University|accessdate=25 April 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150224211510/http://www2.dhu.edu.cn/dhuxxxt/shownewsenglish.asp?id=9930|archivedate=24 February 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> He was named as honorary chairman of [[the Aspen Institute]]. On 21 June 2004, he became the honorary president of [[RCS MediaGroup]].<ref name="rcs28july">{{cite web|title=Vittorio Colao is the new Chief Executive Officer|url=http://www.rcsmediagroup.it/wps/portal/mg/!ut/p/c0/04_SB8K8xLLM9MSSzPy8xBz9CP0os3iXgBDLkGBLIwN_Pw8XA6MAo8BAAycfA2cXU_3g1Dz9gmxHRQCZe6_h/?language=en&WCM_GLOBAL_CONTEXT=%2FRCSMG_Content_EN%2Fhome%2Fleftmenu%2Fpress%20area%2Fpress%20release%2F2004%2Fvittorio%20colao%20is%20the%20new%20chief%20executive%20officer|work=RCS MediaGroup|accessdate=25 April 2013|date=28 July 2004}}</ref>
* [[File:Cavaliere OML BAR.svg|80px]] Knight of [[Order of Merit for Labour|the Order of Merit for Labour]]<ref name="donuni"/>
He also received the Medal of Honor from [[France]].<ref name="donuni"/>
==References== {{Reflist|33em}}

{{Infobox officeholder | name = Charles Alexandre de Calonne | honorific-suffix = [[Count]] [[Hannonville-sous-les-Côtes|of Hannonville]] | image = Charles-Alexandre de Calonne - Vigée-Lebrun 1784.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = Portrait of de Calonne by [[Élisabeth-Louise Vigée-Le Brun]] (1784, [[Royal Collection]]) | office = [[Controller-General of Finances]] | monarch = [[Louis XVI of France|Louis XVI]] | term_start = 3 November 1783 | term_end = 17 May 1787 | predecessor = [[Henri Lefèvre d'Ormesson]] | successor = [[Michel Bouvard de Fourqueux]] | birth_date = {{birth date|df=y|1734|1|20}} | birth_place = [[Douai]], [[French Flanders]] and [[French Hainaut|Hainaut]], [[Kingdom of France|France]] | death_date = {{death date and age|df=y|1802|10|30|1734|1|20}} | death_place = [[Paris]], [[Seine (department)|Seine]], [[French First Republic|France]] | spouse = {{marriage|Marie Joséphine Marquet|1766|1770|end=d.}}
{{marriage|Anne-Rose de Nettine|1788|1802|end=his d.}} | children = 1 son | alma_mater = [[University of Paris]] | profession = [[Politician|Statesman]], [[Parlement|parliamentarian]] }} '''Charles Alexandre de Calonne''' (20 January 1734{{snd}}30 October 1802), titled '''Count of Hannonville''' in 1759,{{cite magazine |author=John Nichols |date=April 1795 |title=The superlatively fine collection of ... |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=38jPAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA286 |magazine=The Gentleman's Magazine |publisher=E. Cave}} was a [[France|French]] statesman, best known for his involvement in the [[French Revolution]]. Realizing that the [[Parlement]] of [[Paris]] would never agree to reform, Calonne handpicked an [[Assembly of Notables]] in 1787 to approve new taxes. When they refused, Calonne's reputation plummeted and he was forced to leave the country. ==Origins and rise to prominence== Born in [[Douai]] of an upper-class family, he entered the legal profession and became a [[lawyer]] to the general council of [[Artois]], procureur to the ''[[parlement]]'' of Douai, ''[[Master of Requests (France)]]'', [[intendant]] of [[Metz]] (1768) and of [[Lille]] (1774). He seems to have been a man with notable business abilities and an entrepreneurial spirit, while generally unscrupulous in his political actions. In the terrible crisis preceding the [[French Revolution]], when successive ministers tried in vain to replenish the exhausted royal [[treasury]], Calonne was summoned as [[List of Finance Ministers of France|Controller-General of Finances]], an office he assumed on 3 November 1783.{{EB1911|inline=y|wstitle=Calonne, Charles Alexandre de|volume=5|page=60}} He owed the position to the [[Charles Gravier, comte de Vergennes|Comte de Vergennes]], who for over three years continued to support him. According to the [[Habsburg Monarchy|Habsburg]] ambassador, his public image was extremely poor. Calonne immediately set about remedying the fiscal crisis, and he found in [[Louis XVI of France|Louis XVI]] enough support to create a vast and ambitious plan of revenue-raising and administrative centralization. Calonne focused on maintaining public confidence through building projects and spending, which was mainly designed to maintain the Crown's capacity to borrow funds.{{cite book |last=von Güttner |first=Darius |date=2015 |title=The French Revolution |edition=1st |location=South Melbourne, Victoria |publisher=Nelson Cengage Learning |page=42 |isbn=9780170243995}} He presented the king with his plan on 20 August 1786. At its heart was a new [[land value tax]], which would replace the old vingtieme taxes and finally sweep away the fiscal exemptions of the privileged orders. The new tax would be administered by a system of provincial assemblies elected by the local property owners at parish, district and provincial level. This central proposal was accompanied by a further package of rationalizing reform, including free trade in grain and abolition of France's myriad internal customs barriers. It was in effect one, if not the most, comprehensive attempt at enlightened reform during the reign of Louis XVI. ==Measures== In taking office he found debts of 110 million [[livres]], debts caused by France's involvement in the American Revolution among other reasons,Ford, F: "Europe 1780–1830", page 102. Longman, 2002 and no means of paying them. At first he attempted to obtain credit, and to support the government by means of loans so as to maintain public confidence in its [[solvency]]. In October 1785 he reissued the [[gold coin]]age, and he developed the ''caisse d'escompte'' (dealing in [[Discounts and allowances|cash discounts]]). Knowing the Parlement of Paris would veto a single land tax payable by all landowners, Calonne persuaded Louis XVI to call an assembly of notables to vote on his referendum.{{cite book|last1=Haine|first1=Scott|title=The History of France|publisher=Greenwood Press|isbn=0-313-30328-2|pages=72|edition=1st}} Calonne's eventual reform package, which was introduced to the Assembly of Notables, consisted of 5 major points: 1) Cut Government Spending 2) Create a revival of free trade methods 3) Authorize the sale of Church property 4) Equalization of salt and tobacco taxes 5) Establish a universal [[land value tax]] [[Image:Calonne.jpeg|thumb|left|200px|Calonne]] All these measures failed because of the powerlessness of the crown to impose them.Crook, M. (2002) ''Revolutionary France'', Oxford: Oxford University Press As a last resort, he proposed to the king the suppression of [[Customs (tax)|internal customs]] [[Duty (economics)|duties]], and argued in favor of the [[Property tax|taxation of the property]] of [[Estates of the realm|nobles and clergy]]. [[Anne Robert Jacques Turgot, Baron de Laune|Anne Robert Jacques Turgot]] and [[Jacques Necker]] had attempted these reforms, and Calonne attributed their failure to the opposition of the ''parlements''. Therefore, he called an ''[[Assembly of Notables|Assemblée des notables]]'' in February 1787, to which he presented the deficit in the treasury, and proposed the establishment of a ''subvention territoriale'', which would be levied on all property without distinction. ==Deposition and exile== This suppression of privileges was badly received. Calonne's spendthrift and authoritarian reputation was well-known to the parlements, earning him their enmity. Knowing this, he intentionally submitted his reform programme directly to the king and the hand-picked assembly of notables, not to the sovereign courts or parlements, first. Composed of the old regime's social and political elite, however, the assembly of notables balked at the deficit presented to them when they met at Versailles in February 1787, and despite Calonne's plan for reform and his backing from the king, they suspected that the controller-general was in some way responsible for the enormous financial strains.{{Citation needed|date=April 2017}} Calonne, angered, printed his reports and so alienated the court. Louis XVI dismissed him on 8 April 1787 and exiled him to [[Lorraine (province)|Lorraine]]. The joy was general in Paris, where Calonne, accused of wishing to raise taxes, was known as ''Monsieur Déficit''. Calonne soon afterwards left for [[Kingdom of Great Britain|Great Britain]], and during his residence there kept up a polemical correspondence with Necker. After being dismissed, Calonne stated, "The King, who assured me a hundred times that he would support me with unshakable firmness, abandoned me, and I succumbed”.France 1789, Victory Over History: The French Revolution (Sydney, 2016), {{cite web |url=http://victoryoverhistory.com/the-french-revolution/france-1789/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-05-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160623195232/http://victoryoverhistory.com/the-french-revolution/france-1789/ |archivedate=2016-06-23 |df= }} In 1789, when the [[Estates-General of 1789|Estates-General]] were about to assemble, he crossed to [[Nord (département)|Flanders]] in the hope of offering himself for election, but he was forbidden to enter France. In revenge he joined the ''[[émigré]]'' group at [[Coblenz]], wrote in their favour, and spent nearly all the fortune brought him by his wife, a wealthy widow. He was present with the [[Charles X of France|Count of Artois]], the reactionary brother of Louis XVI, at [[Pillnitz]] in August 1791 at the time of the issuance of the [[Declaration of Pillnitz]], an attempt to intimidate the revolutionary government of France that the Count of Artois pressed for.Calonne's presence in the entourage of the Count of Artois at this time is confirmed in a journal that documents the events surrounding the coronation of Holy Roman Emperor [[Leopold II, Holy Roman Emperor|Leopold II]] as [[List of rulers of Bohemia|King of Bohemia]] in [[Prague]] in September 1791: the ''Krönungsjournal für Prag'' (Prague, 1791), 203. In 1802, having again settled in London, he received permission from [[Napoleon I of France|Napoleon Bonaparte]] to return to France. He died about a month after his arrival in his native country. ==Legacy== Calonne's negative reputation and assumed responsibility for France's financial crisis in the years leading to the Revolution of 1789 have been judged unfair by historians such as Munro Price. During his position as controller-general, he had genuinely tried to make amends for his previous spendthrift policies. As a contemporary writer, Chamfort, remarked, Calonne was "applauded when he lit the fire, and condemned when he sounded the alarm." Economic historians such as Eugene White,White, Eugene Nelson, (1989), “Was there a Solution to the Ancien Régime’s Financial Dilemma”, Journal of Economic History, 49, 3, pp. 545-568. have however stressed the negative role played by Calonne who continued the restoration of a venal system of financial administration. His fall had important significance to the fate of the monarchy in France before 1789. The financial strains made apparent through Calonne's attempts at reform revealed the instability of the monarchy as a whole, which up until then had been managed on the basis of traditional monarchical absolutism: secretly, hierarchically, without public scrutiny of accounts or consent to taxation. For centuries, the monarchy had controlled fiscal policy on its own terms, and when knowledge of an unmanageable and growing deficit became more widely known, the image was of a failed and, in many ways, corrupt institution. Louis XVI, who had backed Calonne's reform programme wholehearthedly, saw its refusal by the notables and the parliament as a personal failure. Conscientious in his attempts to alleviate the suffering of the French people, the king, it is clear, genuinely hoped to implement an enlightened policy with the help of Calonne. Crushed by this opposition to Calonne's project, the king withdrew to long hours of hunting and larger meals. Many historians see the ensuing months as the beginning of the king's bouts of depression. ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Charles Alexandre de Calonne}} {{wikiquote}} {{Finance Ministers of France}} {{French Revolution navbox}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Calonne, Charles Alexandre}} [[Category:1734 births]] [[Category:1802 deaths]] [[Category:People from Douai]] [[Category:French lawyers]] [[Category:Viscounts of France]] [[Category:18th-century French politicians]] [[Category:People of the French Revolution]] [[Category:French Ministers of Finance]]
