Deceased | lbl23 = | data23 = }} '''Martin Riggs''' is a fictional character from the ''[[Lethal Weapon (franchise)|Lethal Weapon]]'' film series. Riggs was originally played by [[Mel Gibson]] in all four films from 1987 to 1998, and later by [[Clayne Crawford]] in the [[Lethal Weapon (TV series)|Fox television series]] in 2016 to 2018.{{cite news|title=Top 25 Movie Franchises of All Time: #22|publisher=[[IGN]]|date=November 27, 2006|url=http://uk.movies.ign.com/articles/747/747596p1.html|accessdate=September 11, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100726190321/http://uk.movies.ign.com/articles/747/747596p1.html|archivedate=July 26, 2010|df=}}{{cite web|last=Goldberg|first=Lesley|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv/fox-lethal-weapon-finds-mel-gibson-article-1.2560280|title=Fox's 'Lethal Weapon' finds its Mel Gibson|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=March 10, 2016|accessdate=March 11, 2016}}{{Cite news|url=http://tvline.com/2018/05/08/clayne-crawford-leaving-lethal-weapon-season-3-controversy-recast/|title=Clayne Crawford Out at Lethal Weapon, Last-Minute Recasting Underway Ahead of Potential Season 3|last=Ausiello|first=Michael|date=2018-05-08|work=TVLine|access-date=2018-05-09|language=en-US}} Originally a member of the Los Angeles Police Department's Narcotics Division, upon being reassigned to the [[Homicide]] Division, Riggs is partnered up with aging [[sergeant]] [[Roger Murtaugh]]. Riggs and Murtaugh remain partners throughout the film series. == Career == === Military career === Riggs joined the [[U.S. Army]] at age 19, eventually becoming a member of the [[U.S. Army Special Forces]], receiving specialized training in weaponry and hand-to-hand combat. These skills would later serve him well when he became a police officer. Most of Riggs's time in special forces was in [[Vietnam war|Vietnam]], where he served as an assassin under the [[CIA]]'s "[[Phoenix Program|Phoenix Project]]". The first time he became a killer when he shot a man to death with a sniper rifle from a distance in [[Laos]]; while his ability as a trained killer would later plague his [[conscience]], he thought of it as "...the only thing I was ever really good at." === Family === In 1984, Riggs's wife, Victoria Lynn, dies in a car accident, sending him into a deep [[Depression (mood)|depression]]. Driven by grief to the brink of [[suicide]], he regularly puts himself (and anyone else near him) in harm's way, hoping someone will put him out of his misery. This total disregard for his own life makes him literally fearless, turning him into a "Lethal Weapon". By the end of the first movie, however, he has resolved to keep living. In the second film, it is revealed that Victoria was actually murdered during an attempt on Riggs's life.{{cite news|title= The Passion of the Mel|publisher= IGN|date= |url= http://uk.movies.ign.com/articles/106/1064345p1.html|accessdate= 2010-09-11|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100204154327/http://uk.movies.ign.com/articles/106/1064345p1.html|archivedate= 2010-02-04|df= }} === In the films === In ''Lethal Weapon'', Riggs is transferred from the [[narcotics]] division to the [[homicide]] division after a shooting incident. He is partnered with Detective Sergeant [[Roger Murtaugh]] in hopes that the older, more conservative veteran will keep him in line.{{cite news|title= FILM: 'LETHAL WEAPON,' A THRILLER WITH GIBSON|publisher= The New York Times|date=1987-03-06|url= https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9B0DE1DB1230F935A35750C0A961948260&partner=Rotten%20Tomatoes|accessdate=2010-09-11|first=Janet|last=Maslin}} After a rough start, the two become good friends, even though Riggs always gets on Murtaugh's nerves. By the end of the first film, the two have worked together to rescue Murtaugh's daughter, who had been kidnapped by drug lords and military [[mercenaries]].{{cite news|title= MOVIE REVIEW : A Lethal 'Weapon 2|work= [[The Los Angeles Times]]|date=1989-07-07|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1989-07-07/entertainment/ca-3330_1_lethal-weapon|accessdate=2011-05-09|first=Michael|last=Wilmington}} In ''[[Lethal Weapon 2]]'', Riggs discovers that the [[South Africa]]n crime lord, Arjen Rudd, whom he and Murtaugh are pursuing ordered Riggs's death in 1984. Rudd's enforcer, Pieter Vorstedt, killed Victoria Riggs by mistake and made the murder look like an automobile accident to cover up their involvement. After avenging the deaths of his wife and Rika van den Haas (whom Riggs had become involved with romantically before she, too, was murdered by Rudd and his minions), he is able to move on with his life. Meanwhile, Riggs and Murtaugh are assigned to protect a comical federal witness, Leo Getz (played by [[Joe Pesci]]) whom they ultimately become close friends with. He meets Sgt. Lorna Cole (played by [[Rene Russo]]), an [[Internal affairs (law enforcement)|internal affairs]] officer, in ''[[Lethal Weapon 3]]'' during an investigation into the disappearance of weapons from L.A.P.D. impound. The two make an immediate connection and work closely together to clear Murtaugh's name after he is forced to kill his son's friend in self-defense. Riggs and Lorna become romantically involved and move in together after the end of the film. In ''[[Lethal Weapon 4]]'', Riggs and Lorna are still living together, and Lorna is pregnant with their child, but they have dodged the issue of marriage. Both Riggs and Murtaugh are promoted to [[Police captain|captain]] by the fourth film in order to keep them out of trouble, but are demoted back to sergeants at the end of the film. Leo helps Riggs finally make peace with his wife's death; Riggs marries Lorna while she is giving birth to his son. == Television series == {{main|Lethal Weapon (TV series)}} In a March 10, 2016 newspaper article, the plot for the television pilot is as follows: "when Texas cop and former Navy SEAL Martin Riggs...suffers the loss of his wife and baby, he moves to Los Angeles to start anew. There, he gets partnered with LAPD detective Roger Murtaugh...who, having recently suffered a "minor" heart attack, must avoid any stress in his life." ==Weapons== In all of the films and television series, Riggs' sidearm is a [[Beretta 92|Beretta 92F]] 9mm pistol. Riggs is also a practitioner of several styles of martial arts. == Reception == {{Expand section|date=May 2011}} Critics have given the character a positive reception.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jHhbLBgVLS0C&pg=PA116&dq=martin+riggs+martial+arts&hl=en&ei=IGziTdLfEpGr8APZr-GABw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDwQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=martin%20riggs%20martial%20arts&f=false |title=Action Speaks Louder: Violence, Spectacle, and the American Action Movie - Eric Lichtenfeld - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date=2007-04-27 |accessdate=2012-05-07}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ec8w6ZiwQD8C&pg=PA217&dq=martin+riggs+martial+arts&hl=en&ei=IGziTdLfEpGr8APZr-GABw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEEQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=martin%20riggs%20martial%20arts&f=false |title=The Masculinity Studies Reader - Rachel Adams, David Savran - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2012-05-07}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9wS8L4iFvqwC&pg=PA145&dq=martin+riggs+martial+arts&hl=en&ei=IGziTdLfEpGr8APZr-GABw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CEcQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=martin%20riggs%20martial%20arts&f=false |title=Film as Religion: Myths, Morals, and Rituals - John Lyden - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2012-05-07}} He is praised for his dramatic and brutal fight scene with Mr. Joshua (Gary Busey) and the sharp and clever dialogue provided by Shane Black. Martin Riggs is number 100 on Empire's list of The 100 Greatest Movie Characters.http://www.empireonline.com/movies/features/100-greatest-movie-characters/{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JpdHiOnYgrEC&pg=PA251&dq=martin+riggs+lethal+weapon&hl=en&ei=Wm3iTZBLjq7xA4atgYQH&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=martin%20riggs%20lethal%20weapon&f=false |title=Screening Scripture: Intertextual Connections Between Scripture and Film - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2012-05-07}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L37U85DpkNEC&pg=PA27&dq=martin+riggs+lethal+weapon&hl=en&ei=Wm3iTZBLjq7xA4atgYQH&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=martin%20riggs%20lethal%20weapon&f=false |title=High Contrast: Race and Gender in Contemporary Hollywood Films - Sharon Willis - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2012-05-07}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ec8w6ZiwQD8C&pg=PA217&dq=martin+riggs+lethal+weapon&hl=en&ei=Wm3iTZBLjq7xA4atgYQH&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CE8Q6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=martin%20riggs%20lethal%20weapon&f=false |title=The Masculinity Studies Reader - Rachel Adams, David Savran - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2012-05-07}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ue4N9NnHkDgC&pg=PA133&dq=martin+riggs+lethal+weapon&hl=en&ei=Wm3iTZBLjq7xA4atgYQH&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CFUQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=martin%20riggs%20lethal%20weapon&f=false |title=American Masculinity Under Clinton: Popular Media And the Nineties "Crisis ... - Brenton J. Malin - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2012-05-07}} == References == {{Reflist}} {{Lethal Weapon films}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Riggs, Martin}} [[Category:Lethal Weapon]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1987]] [[Category:Action film characters]] [[Category:Fictional Los Angeles Police Department detectives]] [[Category:Fictional characters from Los Angeles]] [[Category:Fictional American people of Scottish descent]] [[Category:Fictional assassins]] [[Category:Fictional Vietnam War veterans]] [[Category:Fictional Central Intelligence Agency personnel]] [[Category:Fictional United States Army Special Forces personnel]] [[Category:Fictional marksmen and snipers]] [[Category:Fictional police sergeants]] [[Category:Fictional police captains]] [[Category:Fictional police detectives]] [[Category:Action television characters]] [[Category:Mel Gibson]] [[Category:Fictional attempted suicides]]

'''Mary Ann Leeper''' is the founder of the [[Female Health Foundation]] (1994) where she became the chair and board member. She was president and COO for ten plus years before retiring in 2013. Leeper also co-founded another organization called the Business Woman's Initiative against HIV/AIDS.{{cite web|title=Mary Ann Leeper, PhD|url=http://www.ourbodiesourselves.org/about/contributors/mary-ann-leeper/}} With Leeper's aid, the newest version of the [[female condom]] will be introduced to women in locations with high rates of [[HIV/AIDS]]. The launch of this new female condom is cheaper and will reach more women. Leeper gives lectures and presentations in colleges and universities across the world. Her main goal is to “help millions of women protect themselves against the spread of HIV and AIDS”. She also stated, “It is not a simple goal, but it is one I am determined to do everything possible to achieve.” == Education == Mary Ann Leeper earned her [[Bachelor of Science]] at Drexel University. She received a [[Master of Science]] at Temple University. Leeper later received her master's degree in business at [[Northwestern University]]'s Kellogg Graduate School of Management. She returned to Temple University to study for her doctorate in pharmaceutical chemistry. == Career == Before retirement, Leeper gave lectures to colleges and universities regarding global entrepreneurship, [[Sexism|gender bias]], [[corporate social responsibility]], women’s issues in the developing world, and prevention programs against HIV/AIDS.{{Cite web|title = Personal Web Page - Mary Ann Leeper|url = http://faculty.darden.virginia.edu/leeperm/index.htm|website = faculty.darden.virginia.edu|accessdate = 2015-12-08}} She was also an assistant professor at [[Temple University]] Schools of Pharmacy and Medicine along with being a [[biochemist]] and director of Neenah Paper Company. Her main focus and overall works revolve around global entrepreneurship, gender bias, women's issue in the world, and lastly female [[Reproductive health|sexual health]] and protection.{{cite web|last1=Hope|first1=Gibbs|title=100 Truly Amazing Women|url=http://trulyamazingwomen.com/the-women/mary-ann-leeper-senior-strategist-female-health-company|website=trulyamazingwomen.com}} === Female condom === Her most recent contribution was the launch of the female condom. She switched from [[polyurethane]] material to [[Synthetic rubber|synthetic latex]], which overall saves manufacturing costs and makes the condom much more affordable. The female condom is an [[Over-the-counter drug|over the counter]] [[Birth control|contraceptive]], which has been [[Food and Drug Administration|FDA]] approved for over 20 years. The female condom gives females an option in choosing the best contraceptive, while remaining sexually active. The female condom contains just as high of a success rate as the [[Condom|male condom]]. It has between 93% to 95% [[pregnancy]] prevention success, which is lower than [[Oral contraceptive pill|oral contraceptives]], injectables, or the [[Intrauterine device|IUD]].{{Cite web|title = Female condoms: Is this the future of safe sex?|url = https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/health-and-families/features/the-future-of-sex-the-first-female-condoms-were-derided-mistrusted-and-shunned-but-will-their-modern-9171710.html|website = The Independent|accessdate = 2015-12-08|language = en-GB}} == Awards ==
United Nation have given her various recognition awards for her work on women's sexual and reproductive health.
Women's Entrepreneurship from Temple University's School of Business (November 2003) As a senior strategic advisor, Leeper has received several prestigious awards, starting from the University of Temple and a recognition award in 2005 and certain United Nations and global health agencies. Along with Mary Ann Leepers’ amazing accomplishments, she also plays a big role in theFemale Health Company’s. She gathers with the MAC, CDC, Department of Health, Female Health Company, and CVS to discuss her personal goal to make female condoms a strong accessible to all women in the country.{{Cite web|title = 100 Truly Amazing Women: Mary Ann Leeper, senior strategist, Female Health Company|url = http://trulyamazingwomen.com/the-women/mary-ann-leeper-senior-strategist-female-health-company|website = trulyamazingwomen.com|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}
== Boards/Committees == *INFLUX (pharmaceutical company) *Board of Visitors (Temple University of Pharmacy) *Board of Advisors (School of Nursing at the University of Virginia) *Northwestern University School of Music Visiting Committee *Board for the Center for Development ad Population Activities (CEDPA) {{cite web|url=http://www.zoominfo.com/p/Mary%20Ann-Leeper/20903811|website=zoom info}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Leeper, Mary}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Temple University alumni]] [[Category:Lecturers]] [[Category:American chief operating officers]] [[Category:Drexel University alumni]] [[Category:Kellogg School of Management alumni]] [[Category:HIV/AIDS activists]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox boxer | name = Michael Gomez | image = Allan Stevenson - Gomez.jpg | realname = Michael Armstrong | nickname = {{plainlist| *The Predator *The Irish Mexican *The Mancunian Mexican *The Manchester Mexican<ref>{{cite web| first=Dean| last=Parr| title=Michael Gomez: The Man, The Myth, The Legend| work=East Side Boxing| url=http://www.eastsideboxing.com/news.php?p=19255&more=1| accessdate=17 October 2009| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090401013152/http://www.eastsideboxing.com/news.php?p=19255&more=1| archivedate=1 April 2009| df=dmy-all}}</ref> }} | weight = {{plainlist| *[[Featherweight]] *[[Super-featherweight]] *[[Lightweight]] }} | height = 5 ft 5+1/2 in | reach = 68 in | nationality = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1977|6|21|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Longford]], [[County Longford]], Ireland | style = [[Orthodox stance|Orthodox]] | total = 48 | wins = 38 | KO = 25 | losses = 10 }}
'''Michael Gomez''' (born '''Michael Armstrong'''; 21 June 1977) is a former [[professional boxer]] who competed from 1995 to 2009. He was born to an [[Irish Traveller]] family in [[Longford]], [[County Longford]], Ireland, spending his early years in [[Dublin]] before moving to London and later [[Manchester]], England, with his family at the age of nine. In boxing he was affectionately known as "The Predator", "The Irish Mexican" and "The Mancunian Mexican".
Despite finishing his career fighting in the [[lightweight]] division, Gomez is more notable for his fights at [[featherweight]] and [[super-featherweight]].<ref name="Boxrec">{{cite web |title=Michael Gomez |publisher=BoxRec |url=http://www.boxrec.com/boxer_display.php?boxer_id=9358 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130407204422/http://www.boxrec.com/boxer_display.php?boxer_id=9358 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=7 April 2013 |accessdate=13 June 2007 }}</ref> During his career he amassed a number of regional championships, most significantly the [[British Boxing Board of Control|British]] [[super-featherweight]] title twice, from 1999 to 2004. He also held the [[World Boxing Union|WBU]] super featherweight title from 2004 to 2005.<ref name="Boxrec"/><ref name="Lonsdale Belt">{{cite web | first=Eamonn | last=O'Hara | title=Gomez bags belt to make history | work=[[The Irish News]] | url=http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:09oh-WGwcDAJ:www.irishnews.com/pageacc.asp%3Ftser1%3Dser%26par%3Dben%26sid%3D319522+%22Michael+Gomez%22+%22Gary+Thornhill%22&hl=en&ct=clnk&cd=17&gl=uk | date=13 December 2000 | accessdate=3 November 2007 }}{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Gomez, who has been compared to [[Johnny Tapia]], has lived a turbulent life and was often involved in controversial fights.<ref name="Bragging Arthur">{{cite web|first=Stephen |last=Jones |title=Alex Arthur v Michael Gomez, Amazing Fighters, Amazing Fight |publisher=Bragging Rights |url=http://www.braggingrightscorner.com/jonesarthur.html |accessdate=31 May 2008 |date=23 October 2003 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070610052958/http://www.braggingrightscorner.com/jonesarthur.html |archivedate=10 June 2007 |df= }}</ref> In Gomez's initial matches he suffered a number of losses to [[Journeyman (boxing)|journeyman]] opposition but then went on a run of victories which stretched for almost four years.<ref name="Boxrec"/> Of his 17 fights between February 2001 and March 2008, 16 ended in [[knockout]]s.<ref name="Boxrec"/><ref name="Bragging Arthur"/> Concerns arose about his drinking and failure to adhere to his [[diet regime|diet]] and [[Boxing training|training]] regimes after a loss to [[László Bognár]] in 2001.<ref name="Back on track">{{cite web|first=Stuart |last=Brennan |title=Back on track |work=[[Manchester Evening News]] |url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/s/25/25033_back_on_track.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130421075741/http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/s/25/25033_back_on_track.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=21 April 2013 |accessdate=31 May 2008 |date=23 November 2002 }}</ref> Gomez appeared to be "back on track"<ref name="Back on track"/> in 2003, with his high-profile fight against [[Edinburgh]]-based fighter [[Alex Arthur]] for the British and [[World Boxing Association|WBA]] Inter-Continental super-featherweight titles, which Gomez won by knocking out Arthur in the fifth round.<ref name="Bragging Arthur"/><ref name="Back on track"/>
In 2006, Gomez suffered a controversial loss to [[Peter McDonagh]] when, in the middle of a round, he dropped his guard and walked out of the ring, later saying he had retired from boxing.<ref name="No Mas">{{cite web | author=Craig Phillips | title=Gomez returns from No Mas fight | work=[[Eurosport]]| url=http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/27042007/58/gomez-returns-mas-fight.html| accessdate=13 December 2007 }} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> He returned to the ring after a 15-month interval. On 21 June 2008, Gomez lost what was seen as possibly his last bout: a [[Last chance saloon#As an English metaphor|last chance saloon]] opportunity to resurrect his career against rising star and Olympic silver medallist [[Amir Khan (boxer)|Amir Khan]].<ref name="Sizzles and Simmers">{{cite web|first=Dan |last=McGovern |title=Hatton Undercard Sizzles and Simmers |publisher=BritishBoxing.net |url=http://www.britishboxing.net/news_378-Hatton-Undercard-Sizzles-and-Simmers.html |accessdate=31 May 2008 |date=5 October 2004 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081123010223/http://www.britishboxing.net/news_378-Hatton-Undercard-Sizzles-and-Simmers.html |archivedate=23 November 2008 |df= }}</ref><ref name="Telegraph Davies">{{cite news | author=Gareth A Davies | title=Amir Khan must not fall prey to Gomez | work=[[Daily Telegraph]]| url=http://blogs.telegraph.co.uk/sport/garethadavies/3664271/Amir_Khan_must_not_fall_prey_to_Gomez/| accessdate=7 May 2008 | date=7 May 2008 | location=London}}</ref> Although scoring a surprise [[knockdown (combat sports)|knockdown]] against Khan early on, the fight ended with Gomez being [[technical knockout|stopped]] in five rounds.<ref name="Doogan Khan">{{cite news | first=Brian |last=Doogan | title=Amir Khan survives knockdown | work=[[The Times|Times online]] | url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/more_sport/article4189159.ece| accessdate=22 June 2008|date=22 June 2008 | location=London}}</ref>
Gomez took the surname Gomez after his childhood hero [[Wilfredo Gómez]].<ref name="Derick Allsop"/><ref name="BP Khan"/>
==Background== Michael Armstrong was born into an [[Irish traveller]] family in Longford, Ireland. His mother went into labour with him while driving, so his [[partially sighted]] father took over the wheel but crashed the car into a lamp post on the way to the hospital; Michael was delivered in the back seat. The Armstrong family moved to [[Ballymun]], Dublin, and, when Michael was age nine, to Manchester, England.<ref name="Derick Allsop">{{cite news | first=Derick |last=Allsop | title=Boxing: Born in back seat of crashed car| work=[[Sunday Mirror]] |date=19 October 2003}}</ref><ref name="The Irish Mexican">{{cite news | first=Paul |last=Howard | title=Self defence; Michael Gomez endured the loss of his parents| work=[[The Sunday Herald]]|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-19059681.html| date=10 December 2000|accessdate=31 May 2008}}</ref>
[[File:Allan Stevenson - Gomez (1).JPG|right|thumb|Padwork with Bobby Rimmer]] Following the family's move to England, Armstrong's father's eyesight failed further due to [[retinitis pigmentosa]]. By that time, there were ten children in the Armstrong family. After his younger sister, Louise, died from [[sudden infant death syndrome]], his mother left the family to live with another woman.<ref name="Telegraph Davies"/><ref name="The Irish Mexican"/> Armstrong subsequently spent much of his youth in various [[orphanage|children's homes]], and was a serial [[truancy|truant]] from school. His mother had taught him to [[shoplifting|shoplift]] as a child, and he was involved in [[Misdemeanor|petty crime]] throughout his youth in Manchester.<ref name="Derick Allsop"/> At nine years old, he began [[Boxing training|training]] at Brian Hughes' Collyhurst and Moston Boys' Club. He also played [[association football|football]] for a local North Manchester team until the club received so many fines for Armstrong's fighting on the pitch that they were unable to pay them. At this point, he stopped playing football to concentrate on his training in the ring.<ref name="Derick Allsop"/><ref name="The Irish Mexican"/><!--<ref name="Born in a car">{{cite web | first=Jerome |last=Reilly | title="Born in a car, dead for 48 seconds, he's a real fighter"| work=[[Irish Independent]]|publisher=| url=http://www.independent.ie/opinion/analysis/born-in-a-car-dead-for-48-seconds-hes-a-real-fighter-126325.html| date=5 February 2006|accessdate=31 May 2008}}</ref>--> During his time in the children's home Armstrong met Alison, who has remained his companion (and later his wife) throughout his professional career; they were parents by the time Armstrong was 17.<ref name="Derick Allsop"/><ref name="TOL family">{{cite news | author=Ron Lewis | title=Michael Gomez: beating Amir Khan is last shot for glory | work=[[The Times]]| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/more_sport/article4159310.ece| accessdate=20 June 2008 | date=18 June 2008 | location=London}}</ref>
==Early professional career== Armstrong boxed as an [[amateur boxing|amateur]] before turning professional in June 1995. He chose the professional surname "Gomez" when the [[British Boxing Board of Control]] (BBBoC) required him to select another name at the time of his registration as a professional; there was [[Michael Armstrong (boxer)|another boxer]] in the same weight division using the name "Michael Armstrong". He chose his ring name in honour of [[Puerto Rico|Puerto Rican]] boxer [[Wilfredo Gómez]], whose videotaped fights Armstrong had studied intently as a youth.<ref name="Derick Allsop"/><ref name="BP Khan"/> The name, combined with Gomez's "[[Boxing#Brawler/slugger|brawl]]ing style",<ref name="ESPN">{{cite web | first=Dan |last=Rafael |title=Rematches don't get any better than Vazquez-Marquez II | work=ESPN.com | url=http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/boxing/columns/story?id=3173659| date=1 January 2008 |accessdate=15 June 2008}}</ref> earned him the nickname of "the Irish Mexican". He developed a ring persona based on this nickname, which has remained popular with fans throughout his career. His ring entrance music is that of a Mexican [[Mariachi]] band, a reference to his [[Spanish language|Hispanic-sounding]] chosen name, and many of his supporters wear [[sombrero]]s to his fights and wave Irish flags. Gomez also wears long Mexican-style boxing shorts in the colours of the [[flag of Ireland]] and often has the shape of a [[shamrock]] shaved into the hair on the back of his head.<ref name="Sizzles and Simmers"/><ref name="BP Khan">{{cite web | first=Rob|last=Tanner| title=Gomez aims to provide Amir Khan with toughest test | work=[[Birmingham Post]] | url=http://www.birminghampost.net/midlands-birmingham-sport/west-midlands-sports/other-sport/2008/05/08/gomez-aims-to-provide-amir-khan-with-toughest-test-65233-20874217/| accessdate=8 May 2008|date=8 May 2008 }}</ref><ref name="Elliot Worsell">{{cite web | first=Elliot |last=Worsell| title=Britain's most exciting fighters: 10 to 4 | publisher=SecondsOut.com| url=http://www.secondsout.com/UK/news.cfm?ccs=228&cs=17005| accessdate=13 June 2007}}</ref><!--<ref name="close call">{{cite web |title=A close call for Ireland's Gomez| publisher=[[The Irish Post]]| url=http://www.irishabroad.com/news/irishpost/sport/closecallforGomez.asp| accessdate=31 May 2008|date=5 October 2004}}</ref> -->
In his debut fight at the [[Manchester Central (Conference Centre)|G-Mex Leisure Centre]], Manchester, England, Gomez beat previously undefeated Danny Ruegg on the [[undercard]] of a [[boxingcard|bill]] that included [[Robin Reid (boxer)|Robin Reid]] and [[Michael Brodie]]. Despite this initial win, Gomez's early career was littered with losses to journeyman fighters such as Greg Upton and Chris Williams.<ref name="Boxrec"/><ref name="Jickells">{{cite web | first=Eamonn | last=O'Hara | title=Gomez in line for title shot | work=[[The Irish News]] | url=http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:c56rR5ZNZ1QJ:www.irishnews.com/pageacc.asp%3Ftser1%3Dser%26par%3Dben%26sid%3D344853+%22Michael+Gomez%22+Jickells&hl=en&ct=clnk&cd=14&gl=uk | date=27 September 2000 | accessdate=3 November 2007 }}{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> [[File:Allan Stevenson - Gomez (2).JPG|right|thumb|Training on bodywork with Bobby Rimmer]]In 1996, Gomez was charged with murder after a [[gang]] fight outside a nightclub in Manchester. Gomez had hit one of his attackers, Sam Parle, who died after his head hit the pavement as a result of the blow. The charge was later reduced to [[manslaughter]] and Gomez was cleared after it was ruled that he had acted in [[self-defense|self-defence]].<ref name="The Irish Mexican"/>
After this shaky beginning in the professional ranks, Gomez had a run of victories from September 1997 to February 1999. During this period Gomez won seven straight fights before challenging for his first title belt, the vacant British Central Area featherweight title against Chris Jickells on 27 February 1999 in [[Oldham]]. Gomez won the title with a fifth-round knockout. He followed his first title win by adding another championship, the [[IBF]] Inter-Continental featherweight title, with a second-round knockout over Nigel Leake.<ref name="Jickells"/>
===Move to super featherweight=== Later that year, Gomez relinquished his championship belts in a bid to move up to the super featherweight division. His first fight in the division, in September 1999, was for the vacant British super featherweight title, against the experienced and much heralded [[Liverpudlian]] fighter [[Gary Thornhill]].<ref name="Boxer of the week">{{cite web|author=Julian Wilson |title=Boxer of the week – Michael Gomez |work=Britishboxing.net |url=http://www.britishboxing.net/news_532-Boxer-of-the-week-Michael-Gomez.html |accessdate=13 June 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927222751/http://www.britishboxing.net/news_532-Boxer-of-the-week-Michael-Gomez.html |archivedate=27 September 2007 |df= }}</ref> Gomez defeated Thornhill with a second-round knockout.<ref name="Boxrec"/> In November 1999, Gomez faced off against [[Mexican people|Mexican]] Jose Manjarrez for the [[WBO]] Inter-Continental super featherweight title, walking away with the title based on the judges' scores after the full twelve rounds. In 1999, Gomez won four title belts, was undefeated during the year and was also named "Young Boxer of the Year" by the British Boxing Writers' Club.<ref name="Lonsdale Belt"/><ref name="Jickells"/><ref name="BBC Thornhill">{{cite news| title=Stylish Gomez retains title | work=[[BBC]] | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/low/other_sports/825889.stm| accessdate=13 June 2007 |date=9 July 2000}}</ref> He continued his winning form into 2000 with another run of six wins, and successfully defended his British super featherweight title against [[Dean Pithie]], Carl Greaves and [[Ian McLeod (boxer)|Ian McLeod]].<ref name="Boxrec"/>
==Bognar and Lear fights== Gomez's first fight in 2001 was on 10 February against [[Hungarian people|Hungarian]] boxer [[Laszlo Bognar]] for the WBO Inter-Continental super featherweight title, in [[Widnes]], Cheshire. Gomez had Bognar on the [[boxing ring|canvas]] in the fifth round, but Bognar recovered from this knockdown and used his [[southpaw]] jab to keep Gomez from closing in. In the ninth round referee Dave Paris stopped the fight following a double left from Bognar, which had Gomez stricken against the ropes. Gomez felt the fight had been stopped prematurely and that he should have been allowed to continue. Gomez later stated that he was suffering from [[influenza|flu]] and should not have taken the fight. The ''[[Daily Telegraph]]'' reported after the match that the pre-fight weigh-in and medical examination were not carried out in accordance with BBBC regulations: the volunteer inspector left before Bognar and Gomez had weighed in, and the medical examiner had not detected that Gomez was ill.<ref name="Boxer of the week"/><ref name="Fighting for control">{{cite news | first=Bob |last=Mee | title=Fighting for control| work=[[Daily Telegraph]] | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/main.jhtml?xml=/sport/2001/02/14/soboxi15.xml| accessdate=31 May 2008|date=14 February 2001 | location=London}}</ref><ref name="BBC Hatton">{{cite news | title=Hatton makes devastating defence | work=[[BBC]] | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/boxing/1427661.stm| accessdate=13 June 2007 |date=7 July 2001}}</ref>
Gomez sought a rematch against Bognar, and five months later in July 2001 the pair met again, this time in Manchester, resulting in a victory for Gomez. The fight started badly for Gomez when he suffered a [[Knockout#Knockdown|flash knockdown]] in the first round and was down again in the second. Gomez came back to knock Bognar down near the end of the second round. Gomez came out firing at the start of the third round and finished the fight with a fourth and final knockdown to avenge his earlier defeat.<ref name="BBC Hatton"/> He followed up his victory over Bognar with a second-round knockout of Scottish fighter [[Craig Docherty]] for another British super featherweight title win.<ref name="Boxrec"/>
His next opponent was unbeaten [[West Ham]]-based fighter [[Kevin Lear]] on 1 June 2002, again in Manchester, on the undercard of the [[Ricky Hatton]] vs. [[Eamonn Magee]] fight.<ref name="Boxrec"/> Lear, a former [[Amateur Boxing Association of England|Amateur Boxing Association of England (ABA)]] champion, kept a one-dimensional Gomez at bay with his sharp [[jab]] from the outset of the fight. Gomez took several punches to the face, and his nose began to bleed heavily starting in the sixth round. By the eighth round Gomez was slowing, suffering the effects of Lear's continuing barrage of combinations. At the end of the eighth round Gomez's trainer Brian Hughes retired his fighter, giving Lear a surprise victory.<ref name="Sporting Life Lear">{{cite web | author=Mark Staniforth | title=Lear Claims Memorable Win | work=[[Sporting Life (British newspaper)|Sporting Life]] | url=http://www.sportinglife.com/boxing/news/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=boxing/02/06/01/BOXING_Manchester.html | accessdate=13 June 2007 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930043634/http://www.sportinglife.com/boxing/news/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=boxing%2F02%2F06%2F01%2FBOXING_Manchester.html | archivedate=30 September 2007 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The defeat to Lear, and the manner in which the fight ended, prompted Hughes, Gomez's longtime mentor and trainer, to ask Gomez to retire from boxing. This event signalled the end of the relationship between Gomez and Hughes; soon after, Gomez crossed Manchester to join Ricky Hatton and former Collyhurst gym stablemate [[Anthony Farnell]] at the rival Phoenix Gym run by Billy Graham.<ref name="MEN Gomez switch">{{cite web | author=Stuart Brennan | title=Boxing: Gomez switches camps | work=Manchester Evening News | url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/s/10/10562_boxing_gomez_switches_camps.html| accessdate=13 June 2007 |date=5 July 2002}}</ref><ref name="frenchman">{{cite news | title=Gomez to fight Frenchman | work=[[BBC]] | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/boxing/3668099.stm| accessdate=13 July 2007 |date=28 April 2004}}</ref> Gomez followed the defeat to Lear with a string of three wins, all by knockout.<ref name="Boxrec"/>
During the period between the first Bognar fight and the loss to Lear, Gomez's life spun out of control. He was "boozing, brawling and womanising",<ref name="Derick Allsop"/> and was convicted of four [[Drunk driving (United Kingdom)|drink-drive]] offenses.<ref name="Back on track"/> During a [[street fighting|street fight]], Gomez was stabbed and badly injured—his heart stopped beating for 148 seconds while on the [[Surgery|operating table]].<ref name="Back on track"/><ref name="Fighting for control"/><!--<ref name="ind">{{cite news | first=Alan|last=Hubbard| title="BOXING: 'Wild child' Gomez set to test Arthur's mettle"| work=[[The Independent on Sunday]]|publisher=Find Articles | url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4159/is_20031019/ai_n12748740 |date=19 October 2003|accessdate=13 June 2007}}</ref><ref name="gamble backfires">{{cite news | first=Bob |last=Mee | title="Alexander's gamble backfires"| work=[[Daily Telegraph]] | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/main.jhtml?xml=/sport/2001/02/11/soboxx12.xml| accessdate=31 May 2008|date=11 February 2001 | location=London}}</ref><ref name="Preacher has faith">{{cite web | first=Stuart |last=Brennan | title="Preacher has faith in Mike" | work=[[Manchester Evening News]] | url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/boxing/s/136/136075_preacher_has_faith_in_mike_.html| accessdate=31 May 2008|date=7 November 2004}}</ref> -->
==Alex Arthur fight== [[File:Allan Stevenson - Gomez (6).JPG|left|thumb|Gomez [[sparring]] with headgear]] Following his change in trainer, Gomez was contracted for the highest profile fight of his career against [[Edinburgh]]-based fighter "Amazing" Alex Arthur for the British and [[World Boxing Association|WBA]] Inter-Continental super featherweight titles. The fight took place in a sold-out [[Meadowbank Stadium]] in October 2003, in what was the first professional boxing card in Edinburgh in almost 20 years.<ref name="Boxing Monthly Amazing">{{cite web|title=Amazing All-Round |work=Boxing Monthly |url=http://www.boxing-monthly.co.uk/content/0310/two.htm |accessdate=13 June 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070812003358/http://www.boxing-monthly.co.uk/content/0310/two.htm |archivedate=12 August 2007 |df= }}</ref>
Prior to the fight, Arthur had opined during interviews that "looking deep into Gomez's eyes at the press conference, I'm not sure even he believes he can win. He'll be so fired up I expect it'll take me eight or nine rounds but, if his resistance has gone as people are saying, it could be a lot sooner."<ref name="Boxing Monthly Amazing"/> With respect to his approach to the fight, Arthur added "I see about 20 ways to beat him. I'm just looking forward to shutting him up."<ref name="BBC Arthur">{{cite news | title=Arthur shrugs off trainer blow | work=[[BBC]] | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/boxing/3193606.stm| accessdate=13 June 2007 |date=15 October 2003}}</ref>
Arthur, who was looking to retain the [[BBBofC]] [[Lonsdale Belt]], was seen as a rising star in British boxing. He was a strong favourite to win the bout against Gomez, who was perceived to have been through too many battles and abused his body too much, and the fight was seen as a stepping stone on Arthur's way to a future world championship.<ref name="Bragging Arthur"/><ref name="Boxer of the week"/> However, [[Freddie Roach (boxing)|Freddie Roach]], Arthur's trainer, was criticised when he remained in the United States to coach another boxer instead of continuing to work with Arthur to prepare for his championship match.<ref name="BBC Arthur"/><ref name=" BBN Kizza Preview">{{cite web|title=Alex Arthur v Michael Kizza Preview |publisher=BritishBoxing.net |url=http://www.britishboxing.net/news_598-Alex-Arthur-v-Michael-Kizza-Preview.html |accessdate=31 May 2008 |date=25 March 2004 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090221071830/http://www.britishboxing.net/news_598-Alex-Arthur-v-Michael-Kizza-Preview.html |archivedate=21 February 2009 |df= }}</ref>
Gomez proved his critics wrong when he arrived at the fight in prime condition and with aggression, determination and desire.<ref name="Bragging Arthur"/> The first two rounds started at a furious pace, with Arthur keeping Gomez at bay with stiff jabs and Gomez working inside with hooks and body punches. The match was turning into a clash of opposing styles, Arthur displaying control and boxing technique and Gomez storming forward with wild ferocity.<ref name="Bragging Arthur"/> From the third round the fight began to turn Gomez's way. Gomez cut Arthur in the third and silenced the home crowd, who were not used to seeing the home-town hero being battered in this manner. Gomez dominated the fourth round and was in full control of the fight—he exposed Arthur's weak defence and at one stage landed 28 punches without reply.<ref name="Bragging Arthur"/><ref name="Gomez stuns">{{cite news | title=Gomez stuns Arthur | publisher=[[BBC Sport]]| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/boxing/3214701.stm| accessdate=31 May 2008|date=25 October 2003}}</ref>
Gomez knocked down his opponent twice before delivering a jarring left hook to Arthur, knocking Arthur to the canvas for the third time. Referee John Coyle stopped the fight, and Gomez won with the resulting [[knock out|TKO]] in the fifth round.<ref name="Bragging Arthur"/><ref name="Gomez stuns"/> The match was hailed as one of the best fights in Britain for a decade. Boxing promoter [[Frank Warren (promoter)|Frank Warren]] called the fight "the greatest contest seen on these shores since [[Nigel Benn]] beat [[Gerald McClellan]] in 1995".<ref name="Kizza Preview">{{cite web | author=K MacInnes | title=This England | work=[[New Statesman]] | url=http://www.newstatesman.com/200311240012| accessdate=13 June 2007 }}</ref> Retired Scottish boxer [[Ken Buchanan]] said it was one of the best fights he had ever seen.<ref name="Bragging Arthur"/>
Gomez attended Arthur's next fight against Ugandan Michael Kizza in Meadowbank, Scotland, but Arthur did not appear when Gomez fought Ben Odamattey for the [[WBU]] super featherweight title in Manchester a few weeks later. Gomez pointed this out when being interviewed shortly afterward, adding "Sky Television want a return. Frank Warren, Arthur's manager, wants a re-match. And most of all so do I."<ref name="GOMEZ BOXING CLEVER">{{cite web|author=Hugh Keevins |title=Gomez Boxing Clever |work=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]] |url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/tm_objectid=14120854&method=full&siteid=89488&headline=boxing--gomez-boxing-clever-name_page.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040426092850/http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/tm_objectid%3D14120854%26method%3Dfull%26siteid%3D89488%26headline%3Dboxing--gomez-boxing-clever-name_page.html |archivedate=26 April 2004 |accessdate=9 June 2008 |date=6 April 2004 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Arthur responded by saying "the fight (with Gomez) is definitely going to happen. Hopefully I'll get another warm-up fight in June and then take on Gomez in September."<ref name="GOMEZ BOXING CLEVER"/> Despite the rhetoric, the two fighters did not meet each other in the ring again.<ref name="Boxrec"/>
==WBU world title== In March 2004, Gomez fought Ghanaian Ben Odamattey for the [[WBU]] super featherweight title at the MEN Arena in Manchester, winning the championship by stopping Odamattey in the third round.<ref name="frenchman"/><ref name="GOMEZ BOXING CLEVER"/> He retained his WBU title in his next two fights against [[Justin Juuko]] and Leva Kirakosyan with knockout wins. Gomez then faced [[Argentinian]] boxer "El Vikingo" Javier Osvaldo Alvarez in February 2005, once again fighting at the MEN Arena in Manchester. WBO super middleweight title holder [[Joe Calzaghe]] had been scheduled to top the bill but pulled out of his arranged fight, and Gomez and Alvarez were slotted as the main attraction.<ref name="porter">{{cite web|author=Mark Porter |title=Alvarez Stops Brave Gomez in Six |work=BritishBoxing.net |url=http://www.britishboxing.net/news_163-Alvarez-Stops-Brave-Gomez-in-Six.html |accessdate=13 July 2007 |date=12 February 2005 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927222610/http://www.britishboxing.net/news_163-Alvarez-Stops-Brave-Gomez-in-Six.html |archivedate=27 September 2007 |df= }}</ref><ref name="Ind Bunce">{{cite news | author=Steve Bunce | title=Alvarez hammer blows put Gomez career on ropes | work=[[The Independent]] | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/boxing-alvarez-hammer-blows-put-gomez-career-on-ropes-1530365.html| date=12 February 2005 |accessdate=13 July 2007}}</ref>
The pair clashed at the weigh in, and this antagonism carried into the ring; from the outset of the fight Gomez tried to draw Alvarez into a [[Boxing#Brawler/slugger|brawl]]. Gomez appeared to win the first two rounds behind stinging jabs, but Alvarez seemed unruffled. In the third round, Alvarez started to take control of the fight and landed several blows to Gomez's face. Gomez began quickly in the fourth round, attacking Alvarez from behind his jab and working his way through his opponent's defense.<ref name="porter"/><ref name="Ind Bunce"/> Alvarez appeared content to catch Gomez as he moved forward. Despite Gomez's strong start, Alvarez dazed Gomez with a stiff right hand shot in the fourth round, after which the Argentinian launched into a furious onslaught. Gomez steadied in the fifth but was visibly tired. Two minutes into the sixth round, Alvarez floored Gomez with a right hook. Gomez [[Professional boxing#Scoring|beat the count]] and Alvarez then moved in to continue his attack. Referee [[Mickey Vann]] stopped the fight after 2 minutes 25 seconds of the round with Gomez pinned to the ropes and taking significant punishment.<ref name="porter"/><ref name="Ind Bunce"/>
==Peter McDonagh controversy== Gomez was out of the ring for almost a year following the Alvarez fight and was next due to fight [[Willie Limond]] for the WBU lightweight title, but turned down the opportunity for a chance to fight for an Irish title. Gomez then signed up to fight fellow English-based [[Irishman]], [[Peter McDonagh]], for the Irish lightweight title on the undercard of a [[Bernard Dunne]] fight on 28 January 2006 at the [[National Stadium, Dublin]]. After the fight was signed Gomez stated "I just can't wait to get my hands on that Irish title because I've been desperate to fight in Ireland for years."<ref name="Born in a car">{{cite web | first=Jerome |last=Reilly | title=Born in a car, dead for 48 seconds, he's a real fighter| work=[[Irish Independent]]|publisher=| url=http://www.independent.ie/opinion/analysis/born-in-a-car-dead-for-48-seconds-hes-a-real-fighter-126325.html| date=5 February 2006|accessdate=31 May 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Bernard Dunne Back in Action on Jan 28 in Dublin! |work=Eastside Boxing |url=http://www.eastsideboxing.com/news.php?p=5585&more=1 |accessdate=13 July 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070804040231/http://www.eastsideboxing.com/news.php?p=5585&more=1 |archivedate=4 August 2007 |df= }}</ref>
Leading up to the fight McDonagh was making visits to see [[paranormalist]] [[Uri Geller]] as "mind coach" to help him prepare mentally for the fight, and Geller also travelled with him to Dublin for the fight. Gomez commented that "I'm not sure Uri Geller will be of much use to him though because there won't be any spoons in that ring for him to bend. The only thing I plan on bending is some of McDonagh's ribs with my body punches."<ref>{{cite web | title=Uri Geller in McDonagh's corner for Irish title fight | work=Irish Independent| url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/boxing-uri-geller-in-mcdonaghs-corner-for-irish-title-fight-119275.html| accessdate=9 June 2008 |date=25 January 2006}}</ref>
The first four rounds were relatively close, with Gomez leading according to pundits, but the fight ended in the fifth round under bizarre circumstances when for no apparent reason Gomez stopped fighting and failed to defend himself. He then received a number of unanswered punches from McDonagh before being floored. Gomez rose from the canvas immediately but appeared to ignore the referee and walk towards his corner while the referee continued with his count. Gomez then left the ring as the referee was waving the fight off. [[RTÉ]] commentator [[Steve Collins]] said "I smell a rat, something's not right here."<ref name="No Mas"/><ref name="Times Foley">{{cite news | author=Michael Foley | title=Gomez controversy a body blow to boxing | work=[[The Sunday Times]]| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/article726946.ece| accessdate=13 July 2007 |date=5 February 2006 | location=London}}</ref><ref name="BBC mcdonagh">{{cite news | title=Gomez trainer slams fixing slur | work=[[BBC]]| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/boxing/4666246.stm| accessdate=13 July 2007 |date=31 January 2006}}</ref>
The [[Boxing Union of Ireland]] (BUI) initially suspended both fighters' [[Prize money|purses]], and investigated reports of unusual betting patterns, with large sums of money being placed on McDonagh to win [[Boxing#Rules|inside the distance]] and more specifically in the fifth round. Odds on McDonagh to win the fight in the fifth round had been cut from 125–1 to 18–1 by the afternoon of the bout.<ref name="BBC mcdonagh"/> Following their investigation, the BUI released the purses to each of the fighters, stating "Michael Gomez and Peter McDonagh confirmed that neither they, their families, nor any person in their camp, as far as they were aware, betted on the fight."<ref name="BUI invest">{{cite web | title=Union awards purses to McDonagh and Gomez | work=[[The Irish Examiner]] (archived at Breakingnews.ie)| url=http://www.breakingnews.ie/archives/?c=SPORT&jp=cweyojcwcwmh&d=2006-02-17| accessdate=9 June 2008 |date=17 February 2006}}</ref> The BUI did express disappointment that the [[bookmaker]], [[Boylesports]], who had suspended wagering on the bout due to the unusual betting patterns, had chosen not to reply to the investigators' queries.<ref name="BUI invest"/> Gomez later explained the loss by saying that "it was all very simple, I just came to a decision in there that I need to retire from boxing full stop".<ref>{{cite web | author=Tomas Rohan | title=Gomez – I'm happy with my decision | work=irish-boxing.com |url= http://irish-boxing.com/january06/31_January_2006_Gomez.htm |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070509185818/http://irish-boxing.com/january06/31_January_2006_Gomez.htm |archivedate= 9 May 2007| accessdate=9 June 2008 }}</ref> Gomez further indicated that he planned to pursue a career in bodybuilding. McDonagh, meanwhile, claimed that he had won because of Gellar's assistance leading up to the bout.<ref name="BBC mcdonagh"/>
Gomez sought a second opportunity to fight McDonagh; in April 2007, he offered to fight for only his training costs.<ref name="MEN Gunning">{{cite web| title=Gomez goes gunning for Amir | work=[[Manchester Evening News]]| url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/boxing/s/1004/1004142__gomez_goes_gunning_for_amir.html| accessdate=11 April 2008 | date=11 April 2007 }}</ref> Finally, their rematch for the Irish lightweight title, to be billed as ''"Redemption"'', was set for 23 May 2008,<ref name="Saddo McDonagh rematch">{{cite web | author=Jane Warburton | title=Michael Gomez gets rematch with Peter McDonagh | work=Saddo Boxing| url=http://www.saddoboxing.com/7106-michael-gomez-peter-mcdonagh.html| accessdate=4 April 2008}}</ref> but McDonagh pulled out of the scheduled bout.<ref name="saddochange">{{cite web|last= Warburton| first =Jane | title = British Boxing: Michael Gomez gets call to face Commonwealth champion Amir Khan June 21 | work = Saddo Boxing | publisher = saddoboxing.com | url = http://www.saddoboxing.com/7311-amir-khan-vs-michael-gomez.html | accessdate=9 June 2008 }}</ref>
==Return to the ring== [[File:Allan Stevenson - Gomez (3).JPG|right|thumb|Gomez working the pads]] Gomez found himself once again drawn to boxing after watching a fight between Alex Arthur and [[Carl Johanneson]], and resumed training. In May 2007, fifteen months after his fight with McDonagh, he returned to the ring to face Daniel Thorpe at the Altrincham Leisure Centre, Manchester.<ref name="feeling the fear">{{cite web|author=Terry Dooley |title=Michael Gomez is feeling the fear but coming back anyway |work=Britishboxing.net |url=http://www.britishboxing.net/news_2551-Michael-Gomez-is-feeling-the-fear-but-coming-back-anyway.html |accessdate=9 June 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080720163122/http://www.britishboxing.net/news_2551-Michael-Gomez-is-feeling-the-fear-but-coming-back-anyway.html |archivedate=20 July 2008 |df= }}</ref>
Gomez had left the Phoenix Gym and was now training at Bobby Rimmers' Boxing Academy in [[Stalybridge]], Manchester, and had returned to fight in the [[super featherweight]] division. The fight was billed as ''"The Last Stand"'', and the venue was sold out with fellow fighters Ricky Hatton and his brother [[Matthew Hatton]] cheering him on from ringside. Gomez won the fight with a stoppage in the third round.<ref>{{cite web | author=Jane Warburton | title=Ringside boxing report: Michael Gomez—Daniel Thorpe | work=Saddo boxing| url= http://www.saddoboxing.com/5241-michael-gomez-daniel-thorpe.html| accessdate=9 June 2008 }}</ref> The following month Gomez also beat Youssef Al Hamidi, again with a third round stoppage.<ref name="feeling the fear"/> Following two comeback fights against journeyman opposition Gomez was rumoured to be in line for fights against many of Britain and Ireland's top level super featherweights and lightweights including [[Kevin Mitchell (professional boxer)|Kevin Mitchell]], [[Amir Khan (British boxer)|Amir Khan]], and Carl Johanneson; Gomez himself was seeking a rematch against Peter McDonagh.<ref name="feeling the fear"/><ref name="MEN Khan">{{cite web | first=Stuart |last=Brennan | title=Khan you believe it? | work=[[Manchester Evening News]] | url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/boxing/s/1006/1006293_khan_you_believe_it.html| date=5 May 2007|accessdate=13 June 2007}}</ref>
He then signed up to face Leeds's Johanneson on 19 October 2007 at the [[Doncaster Dome]], [[Doncaster]], England for the British super featherweight title.<ref name="Boxrec"/> Johanneson had just come off his second defeat to Armenian [[Leva Kirakosyan]], whom Gomez had knocked out in October 2004.<ref name="Boxrec"/><ref name="Nowhere to hide">{{cite web | author=Jim Watt | title=Nowhere to hide | work=[[SKY Sports]] | url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,12067_2807920,00.html | accessdate=19 October 2007|date=19 October 2007 | authorlink=Jim Watt (boxer) }}</ref> Before the fight, Gomez was confident, stating "You can't outbox me. I'll jab your head off. If he comes to have a fight with me it is going to be early Christmas for everyone because I don't know who's going to go but someone's going to go and it's not going to be me."<ref name="jab yer head off">{{cite web|author=Terry Dooley |title=Michael Gomez's considered reflections |work=Britishboxing.net |url=http://www.britishboxing.net/news_2747-Michael-Gomez-s-considered-reflections.html |accessdate=18 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071020014911/http://britishboxing.net/news_2747-Michael-Gomez-s-considered-reflections.html |archivedate=20 October 2007 |df= }}</ref> At the pre-fight press conference in [[Doncaster]] both fighters squared up to each other and promised to knock each other out; during the highly charged face off both fighters had to be kept apart by their promoter and trainers.<ref name="Head To Head">{{cite web|title=Johanneson And Michael Gomez Clash Head To Head |work=Eastside Boxing |url=http://www.eastsideboxing.com/news.php?p=12833&more=1 |accessdate=18 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013094001/http://www.eastsideboxing.com/news.php?p=12833&more=1 |archivedate=13 October 2007 |df= }}</ref>
As many expected, the highly anticipated domestic clash was a savage brawl from round one. Gomez won the opening rounds and threatened to overpower Johanneson from the opening seconds. The Leeds fighter then gained the upper hand as the fight went on, flooring Gomez in the sixth round only for the "Irish Mexican" to rise from the canvas. Soon after, with Gomez appearing unsteady on his feet, referee Mickey Vann stopped the fight.<!--<ref name="Johanneson Stops Gomez">{{cite web | title="Johanneson Stops Gomez in a Thriller!" | work=Eastside Boxing| url=http://www.eastsideboxing.com/news.php?p=12918&more=1| accessdate=20 October 2007 }}</ref><ref name="I deserve"/>--><ref name="Ruthless Johanneson">{{cite news | title=Ruthless Johanneson retains title | work=[[BBC Sport]]| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/boxing/7053918.stm | accessdate=20 October 2007 | date=20 October 2007 }}</ref><ref name="Mail Johanneson">{{cite news | title=Johanneson retains British super-featherweight title | work=[[Daily Mail]]| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/othersports/article-488669/Johanneson-retains-British-super-featherweight-title.html| accessdate=20 October 2007 | date=19 October 2007 | location=London}}</ref> Gomez said that Vann had stopped the fight early, adding, "When the stoppage came, I wasn't wobbling or staggering, and I only dropped my hands in the fight to show Johanneson that he couldn't hurt me. But the referee simply got the wrong message. It was bad refereeing. I told him straight away I was fine, but he insisted on showing me to my corner." The former champion was clear that he wanted another opportunity to fight for the British title.<ref name="I deserve">{{cite web | author=Thomas Myler | title=Gomez: 'I deserve another title shot' | work=[[Irish Independent]]| url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/other-sports/boxing-gomez-i-deserve-another-title-shot-1208649.html | accessdate=31 October 2007 | date=31 October 2007 }}</ref>
==Amir Khan fight== Gomez fought [[Amir Khan (British boxer)|Amir Khan]] for the [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] lightweight title at the [[National Indoor Arena]], Birmingham, on 21 June 2008, Gomez's thirty-first birthday. Khan said that "there is no way he will be as fit as me, so I expect a spectacular stoppage".<ref name="Telegraph Khan">{{cite news | author=Gareth A Davies | title=Michael Gomez vows to beat Amir Khan | work=[[Daily Telegraph]]| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/boxingandmma/2299688/Michael-Gomez-vows-to-beat-Amir-Khan.html| accessdate=7 May 2008 | date=7 May 2008 | location=London}}</ref> Gomez did not attend the scheduled pre-fight press conference, prompting Khan to deride him, and promoter Frank Warren accused Gomez of failing to show respect to Khan and the media.<ref name="Bolton June">{{cite web|author=David Magilton |title=Khan fuming at Gomez no-show |work=[[The Bolton News]] |url=http://www.theboltonnews.co.uk/sport/amirkhan/display.var.2350893.0.khan_fuming_at_gomez_noshow.php |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130422050339/http://www.theboltonnews.co.uk/sport/amirkhan/display.var.2350893.0.khan_fuming_at_gomez_noshow.php |dead-url=yes |archive-date=22 April 2013 |accessdate=20 June 2008 |date=18 June 2008 }}</ref>
During the fight Khan knocked Gomez to the canvas in the first round with a barrage of hooks and uppercuts. In the second round, Gomez caught Khan with a left hook, knocking down the younger fighter and exposing his defensive weakness; however, Khan steadied himself after the mandatory eight-count, and cut Gomez above the left eye before the round ended.<ref name="TeleKhan">{{cite news | first=Mike|last=Lewis | title=Amir Khan given a test by Michael Gomez |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/boxingandmma/2303807/Amir-Khan-given-a-test-by-Michael-Gomez.html | accessdate=2 August 2009|date=22 June 2009 | location=London}}</ref> Gomez caught Khan in the ribs with a left hook in the fourth round which left Khan unstable for a moment, but Khan responded with a flurry of hooks and jabs. Khan landed a "cracking left hook" in the fifth,<ref name="Doogan Khan"/> but Gomez beat the count. At 2:32 of the fifth round, referee John Keane stopped the fight when Gomez was knocked into the ropes by a Khan left uppercut.<ref name="IndepKhan">{{cite news | first=Alan|last=Hubbard | title=Khan cuts loose after early blow | work=[[The Independent|The Independent on Sunday]] |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/general/others/boxing-khan-cuts-loose-after-early-blow-852093.html | accessdate=22 May 2008|date=22 June 2009 | location=London}}</ref> After the fight, Khan said he felt he had moved up a level by "fighting world class fighters like Gomez."<ref name="SkyKhan">{{cite web | title=Tough test for Khan | publisher= [[Sky Sports]] | url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,12183_3720594,00.html | accessdate=22 May 2008|date=22 June 2009}}</ref>
Before the fight, sports writers considered Gomez a tough opponent for Khan, with his "knockout punch" and his success against Alex Arthur in similar circumstances,<ref name="Telegraph Davies"/> despite having lost three of his last six fights.<ref name="skynews june">{{cite web | title=Gomez next up for Amir | work=[[Sky Sports]]| url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,12183_3529531,00.html| accessdate=20 June 2008 | date=6 May 2008}}</ref> Gomez saw the fight as an opportunity to reignite his career; in an interview shortly before the fight he spoke of how "<nowiki>[t]</nowiki>his fight really is my last chance to set myself up for life and become known in every household in Britain".<ref name="Telegraph June">{{cite news | author=Gareth A Davies | title=Amir Khan contest 'surprises' Michael Gomez | work=[[Daily Telegraph]]| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/boxingandmma/2303517/Amir-Khan-contest-surprises-Michael-Gomez.html| accessdate=2 August 2009 | date=17 June 2008 | location=London}}</ref> At the same time, he reflected on the positive effects of his career in the ring, saying "Boxing kept my feet on the ground and gave me a focus. It's got me through the bad times and calmed me down. If it wasn't for boxing, I wouldn't have my beautiful wife and family".<ref name="TOL family"/> Gomez lives with his wife Alison and their three children in Manchester.<ref name="TOL family"/><ref name="MEN Khan"/>

{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Muna Easa Al Gurg | image = File:Muna Al Gurg.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Muna Easa Al Gurg | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates|UAE]] | nationality = [[United Arab Emirates|UAE]] | other_names = | alma_mater = [[London Business School]] | occupation = Managing Director of Retail at [[Easa Saleh Al Gurg Group LLC]] | years_active = 2001-present | spouse = | children = | parents = | relatives = | networth = }} '''Muna Easa Al Gurg''' is a businesswoman and philanthropist from [[Dubai]]. She is Managing Director of retail at [[Easa Saleh Al Gurg Group LLC]] and sits on several boards of directors of companies and non-profit organizations.
Mrs Al Gurg is Chairwoman of Young Arab Leaders, promoting education, entrepreneurship and youth development. She received the Emirates Women’s Award and the Arabian Business StartUp Award for Women in Business.<ref name=GulfNews>{{cite web |url = http://gulfnews.com/business/sectors/general/emirates-women-s-award-honours-outstanding-achievers-1.635596 |title = Emirates Women's Award honours outstanding achievers |author = Zaher Bitar |publisher = Gulf News |date = 2 June 2010| accessdate = 28 November 2015}}</ref><ref name=ArabianBusiness>{{cite web |url = http://www.arabianbusiness.com/revealed-winners-of-first-arabian-business-startup-awards-529330.html |title = Revealed: Winners of first Arabian Business StartUp Awards |publisher = Arabian Business |date = 4 December 2013| accessdate = 28 November 2015}}</ref>
== Career ==
Mrs Al Gurg obtained her BA in Business Administration from the [[American University in Dubai]] and her Executive MBA in Business Administration from [[London Business School]] in 2009.
She started her career with [[Saatchi & Saatchi]] in Dubai. Her first seat on a board of directors was in the Dubai Community Theatre and Arts Centre, where she served from 2004 to 2009, helping build the cultural center.
In 2001, she joined [[Easa Saleh Al Gurg Group]], her family's business and a leading conglomerate in the [[United Arab Emirates]], as director of marketing and communications. She followed the example of her father, HE Sir Easa Saleh Al Gurg and eldest sister [[Raja Al Gurg]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.thenational.ae/business/economy/muna-al-gurg-elder-sister-was-my-role-model |title = Muna Al Gurg: elder sister was my role model |author = Gillian Duncan |publisher = The National |date = 16 December 2012| accessdate = 28 November 2015}}</ref> Since 2009, she has been director of retail, responsible for strategy and operational development for the group’s international and local retail brands.
== Initiatives and charities ==
Since 2008, Mrs Al Gurg has been Chairwoman of [http://www.yaleaders.org/ Young Arab Leaders UAE], where she promotes education, entrepreneurship and youth development. She is a founding board member of Hub Dubai, a non-profit collaborative playground for social, environmental and economic development.
Mrs Al Gurg has been advocating a greater role for women in business.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://vision.ae/articles/beyond_the_glass_ceiling |title = Opinion: Beyond the glass ceiling |author = Muna Al Gurg |publisher = Vision |date = March 2014 |accessdate = 28 November 2015}}</ref> Within Easa Saleh Al Gurg Group, she started the Al Gurg Women's Empowerment Forum, a program providing a platform for women to voice their opinions to company board members. In 2015 she launched the Muna Al Gurg Scholarship at [[London Business School]], supporting female students studying on the school’s MBA and Executive MBA program.<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.london.edu/news-and-events/news/scholarship-boost-for-london-business-school#.Vln4Rby37tR |title = Scholarship boost for London Business School |publisher = London Business School |date = 31 July 2014 |accessdate = 28 November 2015}}</ref>
Mrs Al Gurg has been serving on the board of several non-profit organizations, such as the [http://www.emiratesfoundation.ae/ Emirates Foundation for Youth Development] where she works with Chairman [[Abdullah bin Zayed Al Nahyan]]. At the Easa Saleh Al Gurg Charity Foundation, she is responsible for strategy and initiatives both in the UAE and internationally, including primary education support for underprivileged children in Zanzibar. She is a member of the [[United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees]] Sustainability Board, which is mandated to provide innovative and sustainable solutions to refugees in the MENA region.
Finally, she is a founding board member and Co-Chair of [[Endeavor (non-profit)|Endeavor UAE]], a non-profit organization promoting high-impact entrepreneurship in emerging and growth markets.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.emirates247.com/global-ngo-endeavor-opens-in-dubai-2014-01-16-1.534994 |title = Global NGO Endeavor opens in Dubai |publisher = Emirates 24/7 |date = 16 January 2014 |accessdate = 28 November 2015}}</ref>
== Other activities ==
Mrs Al Gurg is a Fellow of the Middle East Leadership Initiative of the [[Aspen Institute]] and a member of the Aspen Global Leadership Network.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://agln.aspeninstitute.org/projects/job-shadow-day-young-arab-leaders |title = 'Job Shadow Day' (Young Arab Leaders) |publisher = Aspen Global Leadership Network |accessdate = 28 November 2015}}</ref>
She is an opinion columnist for ''[[Gulf News]]'', a major Dubai daily newspaper.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://gulfnews.com/opinion/thinkers/muna-al-gurg |title = Gulf News Thinkers: Muna Al Gurg |publisher = Gulf News |accessdate = 28 November 2015}}</ref>
Mrs Al Gurg is a judge for the Emirates Award for the Arabian Gulf Youth. In 2012, she was a member of the judging panel on the UAE business reality show ''The Entrepreneur''.
== Honors and awards ==
In June 2010, Mrs Al Gurg received the Emirates Women’s Award for outstanding achievers from the hands of Sheikh [[Ahmed bin Saeed Al Maktoum]].<ref name=GulfNews />
In 2013, she was given the Arabian Business StartUp Award for Women in Business.<ref name=ArabianBusiness />
In 2015, she was featured in ''Emirati Women Achievers'', a book with inspiring stories of 21 successful Emirati women.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.tradearabia.com/news/MEDIA_284256.html |title = Emirati Women Achievers book unveiled |publisher = Trade Arabia |date = 15 June 2015| accessdate = 28 November 2015}}</ref>

'''Nicola Tustain''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|MBE}} (born 27 December 1977) is a retired Welsh Paralympic dressage rider. During her career, Tustain won multiple [[para-dressage]] medals at the World Championships and [[Paralympic Games]]. She was named a [[Member of the Order of the British Empire]] in 2010.
==Early life and education== Tustain was born on 27 December 1977 in [[Corwen]], [[Wales]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Nicola Tustain|url=https://www.britishdressage.co.uk/uploads/File/Biographies/Nicola%20Tustain.pdf |website=British Dressage|accessdate=28 January 2018}}</ref> She was born with [[hemiplegia]] that paralyzed her right side.<ref name=horseandhound>{{cite magazine|title=Paralympian Nicola Tustain retires from international competition|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |magazine=Horse & Hound|date=15 April 2009| url=http://www.horseandhound.co.uk/dressage/paralympian-nicola-tustain-retires-from-international-competition-280731|accessdate=28 January 2018}}</ref> She began riding competitively when she was ten years old and participated in a [[Riding for the Disabled Association]] championship when she was twelve. Tustain joined the British equestrian team in 1993.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Healey|first1=Kate|title=Kate Healey talks to Paralympic gold winner Nicola Tustain ahead of her World Para Dressage Championships attempt|work=Daily Post (Liverpool, England)|date=20 July 2007}}</ref> In 1996, she completed a certificate in healthcare at [[Yale College, Wrexham]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Shimmon|first1=Katie |title=College days: Nicola Tustain, medal-winning equestrian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2004/jun/08/furthereducation.uk2|accessdate=28 January 2018|work=The Guardian|date=8 June 2004}}</ref>
==Career== Tustain won her first para-dressage medals at the 1999 World Championships with three gold medals. While competing in the World Championships, Tustain won an additional three gold medals at the 2003 World Championships and a gold and a silver at the 2007 World Para Dressage Championships.<ref>{{cite web|title=World Championships Past Success |url=http://www.equestrianteamgbr.co.uk/competitions/past-successes/world-championships/|website=British Equestrian Federation|accessdate=28 January 2018}}</ref>
Alternatively, Tustain won six Paralympic medals in dressage. At the [[2000 Summer Paralympics]], Tustain won a gold medal in the team and freestyle events with a bronze in the individual event. At the following Paralympics, she won a gold in the team event while winning a bronze in the individual and freestyle events at the [[2004 Summer Paralympics]].<ref name="horseandhound"/>
Other medals include two gold and one bronze at the 2005 European Championships and multiple British Dressage Championships. She retired in 2009.<ref name=BritishDressage2010/>
==Awards and honours== In 2000, Tustain was awarded the [[British Equestrian Federation]] Medal of Honour. In 2003, she was named the best dressage rider by [[Animal Health Trust]].<ref name=BritishDressage2010>{{cite news|title=Nicola Tustain bags MBE for her services to equestrianism |url=https://www.britishdressage.co.uk/news/show/807-nicola-tustain-bags-mbe-for-her-services-to-equestrianism|accessdate=29 January 2018|work=British Dressage|date=28 June 2010}}</ref> The following year, Tustain was nominated for the [[Laureus World Sports Award for Sportsperson of the Year with a Disability]] in 2004 but lost to [[Earle Connor]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Rider Nicola earns Athens call-up |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/wales/north_east/3766059.stm|accessdate=28 January 2018|work=BBC News|date=1 June 2004}}</ref> In 2010, Tustain was named a [[Member of the Order of the British Empire]] at the [[2010 Birthday Honours]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Paralympic champion from Corwen receives MBE|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |url=https://www.dailypost.co.uk/news/local-news/paralympic-champion-corwen-receives-mbe-2737448|accessdate=28 January 2018|work=North Wales Daily Post|date=1 December 2010}}</ref>

'''Paula Donovan''' is an American [[AIDS]] and [[women's rights]] activist. She is the co-executive director with [[Stephen Lewis]] of AIDS-Free World, an international advocacy organization that works to promote more urgent and effective global responses to [[HIV]]/AIDS.<ref>[http://www.aids-freeworld.org/ AIDS-Free World<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> In recognition of her work in HIV/AIDS advocacy, Donovan received the [[Salem Award for Human Rights and Social Justice]] in 2005<ref name="The Salem Award: Paula Donovan">[http://www.salemaward.org/2005_rec.asp The Salem Award: Paula Donovan<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927051525/http://www.salemaward.org/2005_rec.asp |date=2007-09-27 }}</ref> and an alumni humanitarian award from [[Fairfield University]] in 2007.<ref name="Paula Donovan">[http://www.fairfield.edu/ar_fadpauladonovan.html Paula Donovan<!-- Bot generated title -->]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Donovan is also an advocate for [[women's rights]]. She called for the [[United Nations]] to create a UN agency for women with financial and political clout.<ref>[http://www.talktothefuture.org/summer-2008/paula-donovan.html Paula Donovan: A New UN Agency for Women?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091102064134/http://www.talktothefuture.org/summer-2008/paula-donovan.html |date=2009-11-02 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.unmultimedia.org/radio/english/detail/76654.html Activists call for a UN Department for Women]</ref> Her efforts and those of others resulted in the [[UN General Assembly]] passing a resolution in 2010 which supported a new consolidated body, [[UN Women]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unwomen.org/about-us/about-un-women/|title=About UN Women|publisher=UN Women|accessdate=13 January 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116042322/http://www.unwomen.org/about-us/about-un-women/|archivedate=16 January 2013|df=}}</ref> – to be headed by an under-secretary-general – to deal with issues concerning women.<ref>[http://edition.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/09/24/UN.women/index.html Behind the U.N. hoopla, a new agency for women emerges]</ref> The resolution merged the [[UN Development Fund for Women]], the [[Division for the Advancement of Women]], the Office of the Special Adviser on Gender Issues and the [[United Nations International Research and Training Institute for the Advancement of Women|UN International Research and Training Institute for the Advancement of Women (UN-INSTRAW).]]<ref>[http://www.unifem.org/news_events/story_detail.php?StoryID=932 UN to Establish Single New Agency to Deal with Rights of Women]</ref>
Donovan previously served as a Senior Advisor in the office of the [[United Nations]] Secretary General's Special Envoy for [[AIDS in Africa]] and is a 20-year veteran of international development, women's rights and HIV/AIDS.<ref name="The Salem Award: Paula Donovan"/> In the early '90s, she worked at [[UNICEF]] and ran the global advocacy campaign for [[breastfeeding]]. Later, she became chief aide to UNICEF's deputy executive director, and spent four years in Kenya as East and Southern Africa's Regional AIDS advisor for UNICEF.<ref name="Paula Donovan"/>
==Education== Donovan earned both her Bachelor of Arts in English in 1977 and Masters in corporate and political communications in 1988 from [[Fairfield University]].
== References ==
<references/>
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120406132407/http://www.aidsfreeworld.org/About-Us/Who-We-Are/Paula-Donovan.aspx AIDS-Free World Profile] *[https://www.fairfield.edu/lassochannel/press/pr_index/index.lasso?id=1464Fairfield University Alumni Humanitarian Award Profile] *[http://salemaward.org/salem-award/award-winners/2005-paula-donovan/The Salem Award Profile] *[http://www.boston.com/news/local/articles/2005/09/29/working_to_ease_africans_plight/ ''Working to ease Africans' plight]'' by Kay Lazar, [[The Boston Globe]] (September 29, 2005).
